questions.text: A 43-year-old female patient who complains of sudden severe headache, vomiting and neck stiffness is suspected to have SAH and is being planned for investigations. Which of the following is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Ct scan is positive in over 90% of the cases in the first 24 hours.

options.label: B
options.text: False positives can occur if the lumbar puncture is traumatic

options.label: C
options.text: Lumbar puncture can be negative if done less than 12 hours after the bleed

options.label: D
options.text: Xanthochromia may be detected by the naked eye in many cases if the lumbar puncture is done within 24 hours of the bleeding.

questions.correct_answer: D. Xanthochromia may be detected by the naked eye in many cases if the lumbar puncture is done within 24 hours of the bleeding.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Xanthochromia may be detected by the naked eye in many cases if the lumbar puncture is done within 24 hours of the bleeding. Xanthochromia will not be detectable to the naked eye 2 hours after the bleed. It is usual to perform LP 12 hours after the onset of the headache.

Highyeild:

SAH (Subarachnoid Haemorrhage) : ‘Spontaneous’ SAH is usually the result of bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm (approximately 80% of SAH) or an arteriovenous malformation (AVM) Most result from the rupture of an aneurysm in the circle of Willis Plain CT and lumbar puncture are first-line investigations Even ‘good grade’ patients treated promptly have significant morbidity owing to vasospasm, cardiac arrhythmias, neurogenic pulmonary oedema, etc. Treatment : Surgical: Craniotomy and Clipping or Coiling(Endovascular Embolisation) Medical: Oral Nimodipine, Analgesics, Laxatives, Antiemetics, compression stockings

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: With 3rd generation CT scanners, SAH can be diagnosed on CT scan alone with > 90% accuracy within the first 24 hours after the bleed. Option B & C If the history is good and the CT scan is negative, LP must be performed. Lumbar puncture must not be performed too early as xanthochromia takes time to develop. It is usual to perform LP 12 hours after the onset of the headache. A traumatic tap can cause confusion. Spectrophotometry of CSF is very helpful. A bilirubin peak is diagnostic of SAH.

Extraedge:

Hyponatraemia is a frequent complication of SAH, attributed to cerebral salt wasting in the context of fuid depletion and to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion otherwise Fluid restriction is not appropriate in these patients since this risks further compromising perfusion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presents after a motor vehicle crash. The patient was unresponsive at the scene and was intubated by the EMS team. Her vital signs include a heart rate of 89 and systolic blood pressure of 150 mm hg. Initial primary and secondary assessments were unremarkable, and the eFAST examination was negative. The patient undergoes a CT scan and on returning from the scan is observed to have a new finding of a blown right pupil. What is the next most appropriate course in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Observe the patient for further changes

options.label: B
options.text: Consult neurosurgery for an ICP bolt

options.label: D
options.text: Elevate the head of the bed, hyperventilate, and order a bolus of mannitol

questions.correct_answer: D. Elevate the head of the bed, hyperventilate, and order a bolus of mannitol
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Elevate the head of the bed, hyperventilate, and order a bolus of mannitol The blown pupil should cause one to be concerned about increased intracranial pressure. Initially, emergent protocols to reverse the ongoing process are critical. The patient is already intubated, hence hyperventilating the patient, elevating the head of the bed and bolus of mannitol are actions that could be quickly performed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A & B: Delaying therapy for imaging results or consultation with another service should be avoided. Option C: There is no indication for steroid therapy in head trauma. (clearly demonstrated by crash trial)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented in the casualty with two hours history of sudden onset of severe headache associated with nausea and vomiting. On clinical examination, the patient had neck stiffness and right-sided ptosis. The rest of the neurological examination was normal. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage Presence of 3rd nerve palsy with signs of meningism mandates ruling out a PCA aneurysm in all cases before further evaluation.

questions.text: A 45- year- old female patient who presented with a sudden severe headache underwent a ct brain and was diagnosed to have a subarachnoid haemorrhage. The therapy for her includes all except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypothermia Triple H therapy of subarachnoid haemorrhage used to ameliorate cerebral perfusion consists of- Hypervolemia Hypertension Haemodilution

Highyeild:

Management : Patients should be placed on bed rest with hourly neuro observations. They require strict input–output monitoring and intravenous fluid replacement with normal saline initially. Oral nimodipine at a dose of 60 mg every 4 hours reduces the rate of poor outcomes. Analgesics, laxatives, anti-emetics, gastric protection and compression stockings are also likely to be necessary. After resuscitation, the priorities in subarachnoid haemorrhage are To prevent rebleeding by identifying and controlling any underlying lesions To recognise and manage: Neurological complications, especially vasospasm (or delayed ischaemic neurologic deficit) and hydrocephalus Systemic complications, including electrolyte imbalance, severe hypertension, cardiac infarct and arrhythmia, and neurogenic pulmonary oedema.

questions.text: A 45- year- old hypertensive male patient presented with sudden onset most severe headache, vomiting and neck stiffness. On examination, he didn’t have any focal neurological deficit. His CT scan showed blood in the Sylvian fissure. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ruptured aneurysm Spontaneous subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is usually the result of bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm (~80% of SAH) or an arteriovenous malformation (AVM). Most ruptured aneurysms are located in the circle of Willis, at branch points in the arterial tree associated with turbulent blood flow Spontaneous intracerebral haemorrhage accounts for 10–15% of strokes and has a mortality of 40% in 1 year. The majority occur in the context of hypertension or amyloid angiopathy or as a complication of ischaemic stroke. Coagulation disorders, especially among patients being treated with warfarin, are a major risk factor. Patients typically present with a sudden focal deficit and reduced consciousness level.

questions.text: A 70- year- old female patient who complained of severe headache associated with marked neck rigidity and no focal neurological deficit was subjected to a CT scan which showed the following finding. Identify the condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subarachnoid haemorrhage Subarachnoid haemorrhage from trauma consists of bleeding into the spinal fluid spaces surrounding the blood vessels feeding the cerebral cortex.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Subdural haemorrhage occurs in the potential space between the dura and arachnoid. This is often the result of shearing of the bridging veins between the brain and the dural venous sinuses. Sometimes, it comes from injury to cortical vessels, which then bleed into the subdural space. It appears as a convex-concave hyperdensity on CT Option D: I ntraventricular Haemorrhage occurs inside the ventricle and can be associated with subarachnoid haemorrhages
